Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: They are expected to deep clean every room, ensuring all areas are thoroughly sanitized.
Story: It’s Saturday morning, and my phone buzzes with a message from my mom: “Hope you’re doing well, sweetheart. Miss you!” I know she wants me to call, to hear my voice, to feel that I’m still close even though I moved out last year. I glance at the clock—my shift at the hotel started an hour ago, and I’m only halfway through scrubbing the bathrooms. The supervisor just reminded us that every corner needs to be spotless today; there’s a big inspection coming up. My hands ache from the bleach, and my mind races with guilt. I want to send a long reply, maybe even call my parents and tell them about my week, but I can’t risk falling behind. If I don’t finish on time, I’ll let my team down and maybe even lose hours next week. I stare at my phone, torn between the warmth of my family and the pressure of my job, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
